The selection of philosophers for this semester was generally good. This course has a very clear and precise arc, beginning with the various types of enlightenment philosophers, moving onto the anti-enlightenment, and concluding with the democratic project. The readings may at times be of interest, though I do not believe that it is possible, with everything else going on, for a student to truly finish all the readings comprehensively. Some are relevant but others may sometimes be tangential to what is taught in class or discussed in section.
I learned about the basic structures of political philosophy while taking this course. I also learned that I am not interested in pursuing this subject further due to personal preference.
none

I thought the course was poorly advertised -- it felt like we (confusingly) walked through each thinker and their theory and very rarely considered their theory's applications to the present day.

My critical writing abilities, my analytical reading skills, and my general faculty for inquisitiveness and the formulation of normative ideas about my environment, particularly my political circumstances.

This course taught me to evaluate politics in a variety of different ways. I now consider what I have learned about numerous different political philosophers before making up my mind on various issues.

In this course, I learned essential foundations for my future studies. Hearing about Locke or Robert Nozick or Edmund Burke without having read their seminal works or discussed their ideas can be confusing or meaningless. This course provided an opportunity to learn about political philosophers of all stripes within the Western tradition, and it will serve me well in future studies. I also found myself surprised by the fact that many of the thinkers were thoroughly convincing despite providing the foundation for modern political traditions, like American conservatism, that I definitely reject.

This course is an excellent survey of political thought. Professor Shapiro places a refreshing emphasis on old ideas applied to modern political issues, as well as on twentieth and twenty-first century thinkers. This is really rare for most introduction to political philosophy courses. He is a highly original thinker who makes interesting connections between very different thinkers across time. In general, this course is great for recognizing patterns, a skill that any discipline requires. Moreover, my writing and critical thinking improved tremendously in this course.
MoFoPo is a fantastic introduction to political philosophy. It made me question assumptions I had held for the entirety of my life and think deeply about moral questions which we tend to ignore.
I learned how to compare political thinkers in-depth across time and theory.
Comparing different political philosophies.
I gained an understanding of the historical philosophical approaches to modern political questions.

I learned how to engage with the theories of classic (white) political philosophy. I took the writing section and enjoyed it-- you get good feedback on your papers and if you havent written a more abstract philosophy paper before and you want to get some practice, this is a good class to do it in. also an easy writing credit

MoFoPo is an incredible introduction to the world of politically philosophy, importantly implied to current events and issues. Shapiro offers the class great introductions to modern political thinkers, and section helps students parse through the texts and work through the thinkers' applications. This is a great class to take as an introduction to political thought, and it's a fantastic foundation for future courses in theory.
Ability to write a well-organized political philosophy paper.
I learned the political philosophies of many different thinkers.
A basic understanding of several political philosophers.

This course taught me to develop convincing, coherent arguments, above all: because the course was a survey of different thinkers throughout time attempting to erect a strong theoretical framework of society and government, the course exposes one the different methods, strategies, thought experiments, argumentative patterns that were used in doing so, giving one the proper footing to begin to develop one's own arguments. Thanks to this course I also began to think more critically of the arguments made around me--of their logic, their effectiveness.

The political philosophies we learned in this course mostly centered around the questions "to what extent should we have government?" and "what role should the government play in a state?" Since we examined the enlightenment and then the anti-enlightenment for most of the course, the most important topics were liberty/rights and equality/redistribution.
I became a more nuanced and critical thinker and learned to challenge and defend my own ideas. I feel pretty confident tracing the sweep of political philosophy from the Enlightenment on.

I can say with confidence that I know how to approach political philosophy a lot more than I did at the beginning of the semester, especially the sort of thinking and analyses required. Capitalism is also always seen as the default and as inescapable, and there was not a lot of room in the course to imagine a society without it.

Strengths: A catchy title and a bold promise that tricked me and other friends into taking the class. If you're looking to pick up a WR credit without actually improving your writing, MoFoPo will allow you to accomplish that. Other than that, not much.

Weaknesses: Where do I begin? I could start with the final exam, when the class was stuffed like pigs into our usual, cramped lecture hall for a 3.5-hour in-class essay exam that featured a hypothetical, frankly ridiculous essay question. Not enough exams were printed for the class, delaying the process and further ensuring that the open-note test wasn't an intellectual one but instead one that valued how fast you could write, how much you could write, and how much information you could take from your notes or an online study guide to the blue book. Or I could start with the fact that classmates and I still haven't been returned our second essay as students that opted into the WR-credit track. We wrote two 8 to 10-page essays and none of the comments I have received have been focused on improving my writing; instead, they're all concentrated on the philosophical theories students are expected to twist both ways to satisfy a thesis.

Readings are dense and abstract, and Shapiro doesn't do a good job of illustrating how the material connects under the arc of the course or to current politics. Lectures often focus on the minute details of a theory without first giving students the broad overview necessary for engaging with the content. Throughout the semester, it felt like we grabbed at random ideas and theories without fully unifying them under concrete themes or progressions. MoFoPo is poorly organized and circuitous. My TA was replaced about 5 or 6 weeks into class, adding chaos to what was already a chaotic situation, and though my new TA was smart and helpful, I continually felt like I lacked a proper road map for the class that would have helped me contextualize the philosophical niblets that were hurled at me from all sides. 

The class carries an inflated sense of self-importance and feels ridiculous sometimes (like the absurd hypothetical question and conditions during the final exam, which counted as 50% of the course for non-WR students and more than one of our 8 to 10-page essays as WR students), as if you can argue anything if using the right jargon and name-dropping enough key terms/key thinkers. Shapiro and course coordinators must abandon the notion that the class doesn't need to adapt to better serve its students or support its TAs.

A deeper analysis of their backgrounds, aims, and points of commonality in this regard might help for overall situation of the different texts and their contained ideas.

The weaknesses were that the lectures were sometimes hard to follow and not as in depth as necessary to create understanding. I did not feel as thought the section classes prepared us well for essays or exams, but they were enjoyable.

The strengths of the course are the engagement with the political philosophies discussed and the level of detail arrived at. Instead of presenting a history of ideas, the professor and class actively evaluate the philosophies read about. Further, the philosophies presented were just the right level of complexity for an introductory course. The weaknesses of the course are the problems that could arise by missing one class, since the lecture notes were rather light and the material too difficult to comprehend individually.

For anyone interested in filling in the gaps in their knowledge about political theory, this course covers a lot of ground. For people not familiar with political theory, this course demands a lot and requires a lot of reading, so it is important that people are aware of the challenges that this course presents. One of the weaknesses is the divide between individuals that are more comfortable with the material and those that are just starting out an interest in political theory. Gauging the levels of comprehension and prior knowledge of students in the course before the semester progresses might help those that feel that discussions might go over their head at times.

Ian Shapiro is a wonderful lecturer, and he mixes humor and academics in his slides in a very enjoyable way. This being said, it was difficult to study the slides in preparation for exams or essays because the slides themselves do not contain much information on the authors; I will not raise this comment to the level of a critique, for the best way to fresh up on an author's thoughts and theories is to read the author again, not copy information off of a power point. 
The essay prompts, and the exams for this class, were outstandingly engaging and fun to write and take. The material that we read, additionally, gives a valuable overview of how different thinkers tackled the issue of morality in politics. 
The greatest weakness of this course, I will have to say, and this may only pertain to my own personal experience, were the sections. I found that discussion in them was unproductive. I need to mention that this was not the fault of the TA, by any means: because many students simply do not have adequate time to read and think about an author's work, sections became, for me, a group of students who had not done the reading properly fumbling around in the dark in a glorified way.

No. This has been my least favorite class at Yale and since I gained the freedom to choose my classes in high school. 

I feel like I gained unconnected pieces of knowledge about certain thinkers and their ideas and don't feel like I am a better writer, thinker, or philosophy student. Throughout the semester I lacked the context and organization that would have helped me make the most of the material. Even as students reviewed for the final exam, instructors were hands-off in setting the agenda/structure, as many sections operated. TAs hosted a few final exam review sessions that required students in attendance to ask questions that would then spark review and be answered by other students in the crowd as part of a "review discussion." The result? We touched on lot of material, moving through most thinkers in the course in a 90-minute session. But when you lack an authoritative force that helps to deliver the material in an organized, contextual way, all the key terms and ideas pool very unhelpfully. I left the review session reminded of a lot of snippets of ideas and theories but even more confused. Nothing seemed like it logically connected, and that fell on the instructors who are supposed to administer and control the flow of information in a class, especially when all of a course's readings are primary sources that don't thematically connect on the surface.

I will warn the prospective student, however, not to take this class to lightly. Although you can get by in this class by not reading the texts super intensely, the student who really wishes to do well and gain a strong grasp on the thinkers in this class will need to recognize the hours that need to be put into readings. 
In other words, if you want a fun class that's not too hard that will expose you to many different thinkers trying to answer problems of government interference, people's liberties, and more, you will have a good time taking this class. The beauty of this class is this: if you want to make this class more challenging, however, you can always do so by going even deeper into the arguments of all these authors.
